SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A NOTE OF APPRECIATION TO THE PERSON RESPONDING TO THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to compress a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer. Do not worry about leaving blank spaces. The purpose of these questions is not to collect information, but to assure that questions are included to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1905, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

2. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

I was the first in my family to come to Western Canada. My parents came five years earlier, so it would have been easier for them.

24. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitements etc.)

I remember meeting relatives at Athabasca, but I don't recall their names. We also met a man named Mr. Smith who was very kind to us.

14. How long did it take you to reach your destination?

It took us about six weeks to reach our destination.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at a small tent and then moved into a house near the town.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We settled in the town of Weyburn.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

From 1900 to 1922 we lived in Brandon, Manitoba. From 1922 to 1932 we lived in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. From 1932 to 1947 we lived in Weyburn, Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

From age 14 to 16 I worked as a farmhand in Brandon, Manitoba. From 1922 to 1932 I worked in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. After arriving in Western Canada, I worked as a laborer in Weyburn, Saskatchewan.
21. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

A was the first to come to Western Canada. My parents came five years later, and my children and I would follow.

24. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

Remembering my trip to Alberta, I had never been there before. We went on to Regina, then to Prince Albert, and finally to Edmonton. We traveled in a covered wagon and there always three of us. We got there after about 14 miles from Regina (Saskatchewan) to Edmonton. We traveled in a covered wagon and there were three of us. We got there after about 14 miles from Regina (Saskatchewan) to Edmonton.

25. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at a small town called Edmonton. We stayed there for about two weeks.

26. Where did you settle or take up land?

8.04 acres. T8.R8.West 2nd (I used to own it)

27. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

From 1900 to 1922 I lived in Edmonton. From 1922 to 1932 I lived in Prince Albert. From 1932 to 1947 I lived in Prince Albert. During the two years away I lived in Grande Prairie. Calgary. 8.0 acres.

28. How long did you live before coming to Western Canada? How long have you lived in Canada?

I came age 14 to 20 and lived in Canada for many years. At that time the Y.E.A. was very strong about itself. A church and where I worked was in the same field. After coming I went working on farms at fifteen years old.

I have filled in your form to the best of my recollection and turned it into the hands of Mr. Smith. One experience I had is worth the time to quote here.

On making my first trip to Montana for fuel to keep my house warm, I stopped to inquire at a farm house where I could get water. My owner said they had not had a drink all day. I was told I would find along the road near the trail after traveling what seemed quite a long way. I knew some water not far from trail and needed my own. Toward the end of the journey I heard footsteps. The men being followed for drink made a race for the water but on account of thin heads found it was white ahead and the water was probably 25° of fever. They immediately they were into the mud right up to their knees. I jumped to the front of the wagon gear and yelled and shouted the trip and they came running around and out. They had been down in mud at least three feet. A neighbor of mine took a team of horses the same way home. Time later the good Lord was surely with me for if not I got out very safely.
I have filled in questionnaires to the best of my recollection and trust it will be of some help to your poems. One experience I had is worth the trouble to quote here.

On making my first trip to Montana for the purpose of homesteading, I stopped to inquire at a farm house where I could get water. My host was very kind and offered me a drink all day long. I was told I would find plenty of water near the trail. After travelling what seemed quite a long way, I came upon water not far from trail and headed my oxen towards it. Through some accident, however, the oxen being frightened for drink made a race for the water first on discovery of their heads. It was white ash, mud, and the water was probably not fit for anything immediately they were into the mud right up to their bodies. I jumped to the front of the wagon gear and yelled and shouted the whole way down the trail. They have been down in mud at least three feet deep. A neighbor of mine took a team of horses the same way some time later. The ground was very muddy with me for a fellow. I got out very dirty.
I would have gone down also.

The summer of 1900 was extremely dry and no snow the previous winter. About Aug. 5th it started raining and every other night for weeks there was a heavy thunderstorm.

That summer settlers further east came long distances looking for hay to cut. Some had hay cut and coiled in the very deep sloughs very soon the water covered the hay.

There was only one slough for miles around where all settlers watered their animals and I was fortunate enough to live within half a mile of it. For drinking water I dug a hole in center of a very deep slough close by and got some soakage water. (This was early spring)

I might state I was one of the pioneer growers of grass for seed. In 1907 I sold my first Western rye seed to McKenzie Seed Co. Brandon. After that I increased my acreage every year and cleaned and petalled my seed and there was very few towns or prairies that I didn't ship seed to. Mr. Pearson of the Dom Seed branch at back has been at my farm a great many times inspecting my brown seed of later years.

Yours very truly,

L.W. Burns

That summer settlers further east came long distances looking for hay to cut. Some had hay cut and coiled in the very deep sloughs very soon the water covered the hay.

I might state I was one of the pioneer growers of grass for seed. In 1907 I sold my first Western rye seed to McKenzie Seed Co. Brandon. After that I increased my acreage every year and cleaned and patented my seed and there was very few towns or prairies that I did not ship seed to. Mr. Pearson of the Dom Red brand at back has been at my farm a great many times inspecting my home seed of later years.

A sun-set in Sockatshawan
As hard rain pours a Prairie City
Just as the sun goes down
I feel really missed a Heavenly Night
A grandeur night dear me in Kefund
Its Javelins red, blue, pink and gold
With two and tints named not the names
For trying to paint a scene like this
Mans art at best is only shamed.

Sometimes upon the western trim
This color scheme we see
Some other purple night o'knight
It spreads out a vast canopy
No poem like this can be compared
To what of world I've traveled round
If we but really Gods former
If then we will stand on holy ground.

P.S. I composed this little poem five years ago when on a trip back to Kingston and after witnessing a beautiful sunset. Should perhaps you might think fit for the archives.
A poem in Sonnet form

As the last rays peer a Prairie sky
Just as the sun goes down
Painted really mimic a heavenly sight
A garden's plight seen in profound
Its jewels red, blue, pink and gold
With hues and tints named not to named
For trying to paint a scene like this
Mans art at best is only shamed.

Sometimes upon the western rim
This calm scheme we see
Some other paints night o'knight
It spreads out a vast canopy
Two poems like this can be compared
In what of world has traveled round
If we but realize Gods former
If then we will stand on holy ground.

P.S.
